item.title: Starbucks Reports Record Quarter, but Challenges Remain
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
A Record Quarter, but Traffic Was Down and Expenses Are Up

Starbucks reported record third quarter sales of $6.3 billion, up 11% from last year, and GAAP earnings per share of $0.62 and adjusted EPS of $0.62, up 30% and 13%, respectively, year over year. Comps increased 1% on a consolidated basis, a further slowing of growth from the 2% comps increase in both the first and second quarters of the year.

A closer look at comps offers some reason for concern. In prior years, Starbucks was able to consistently grow comps at or above — in some cases well above — 3%, from a mix of higher traffic and bigger tickets. However, over the past year, traffic has been relatively flat, while bigger tickets have done all the heavy lifting. Unfortunately, it’s starting to look like Starbucks is developing a traffic problem.

Here is a breakdown of comps by geographical segment last quarter:

Comparable-Store Sales

Sales Growth

Change in Transactions

Change in Ticket

Consolidated

1%

(2%)

3%

Americas

1%

(2%)

4%

China/Asia Pacific (CAP)

(1%)

(3%)

2%

Europe, Middle East, Africa

0%

(2%)

3%

Data source: Starbucks.

As the table shows, Starbucks sold more goods — or higher-priced goods — to fewer customers in every market last quarter. But there is some additional context to consider. On the earnings call, Chief Operating Officer Roz Brewer said that a decline in Frappuccino sales and the May 29 anti-bias training closure took a three-point bite out of the Americas segment, though only about one-half point of that was due to the store closure.

Comps in China fell 2% in the quarter, a sharp turn negative after what had been steady positive growth. This weak result caused the CAP segment to report negative comps in the quarter, driven by a 3% decline in transactions.

Operating margins also declined in the quarter, falling from 18.4% last year to 16.5%. The company said the decline was a product of higher spending on store employees, the increased mix of food sales, and the impact of taking full ownership of the mainland China stores late last year.

Essentially all of Starbucks’ operating income decline was related to its U.S. operations. Americas segment operating margin declined 2.9 percentage points to 21.5%, and operating income fell $66 million, while operating income increased in all of Starbucks’ other segments. Consolidated operating income declined $6 million.

On the earnings call, CFO Scott Maw said that the increased expense in the quarter was a product of several things, including planned increased spending on employees, the impact of higher food mix, planned investments in technology, and the impact of the May 29 U.S. store closure.

Blame It on Frappuccino and No Coffee Culture?

Maw also said that management now expects its full-year comps to come in slightly below the low end of the company’s 3%-5% growth range, as its expectations are relatively muted for the fiscal fourth quarter. This is likely driven by continued unexpected weakness in sales of its blended Frappuccino beverages, which have declined 3% in 2018, after growing 17%, 5%, and 4% in the prior three fiscal years.

On the other hand, non-coffee beverages, including Teavana-branded teas, continue to perform well, as do sales of food. Teavana and refreshment beverages have increased at least 12% for four consecutive years, and were up 14% year-to-date through May 2018, while food has accounted for 22% of sales this year. On the earnings call, management said that it was seeing growth in every beverage segment, and food, with the exception of Frappuccino. Unfortunately, the positive results from its other products are not enough to offset weak Frappuccino sales.

Management is clearly concerned about comps in China, but its bigger focus is on store expansion. The company aims to expand from 3,000 stores in 100 cities at recent count, to 6,000 stores in 230 cities by 2022. On the earnings call, China CEO Belinda Wong emphasized that China is still a developing coffee market, and that a big part of the company’s long-term success there will be tied to its ability to expand the market and continue introducing more and more people to coffee.

Looking Ahead

As the company moves closer to fiscal year-end, it continues to tweak its earnings guidance. Management revised guidance for GAAP earnings up from $3.23-$3.26 per share to $3.26-$3.28 per share, and tightened the non-GAAP range from $2.39-$2.43 per share to $2.40-$2.42 per share. And as discussed above, global comps are expected to be at the lower end of the 3%-5% range next quarter and below 3% for the year.

Management also committed to taking steps in fiscal 2019 to drive better returns, including accelerating the closure of underperforming company-owned stores and focusing new expansion on its best markets, while opening fewer licensed stores in the U.S. China, on the other hand, is set to see an acceleration of new store expansion, with the company planning to increase its pace by 20% starting next year.

There are legitimate challenges in front of Starbucks, including retail weakness in the U.S. and speed bumps in China as it aggressively develops that largely untapped market. But with a powerful brand and history of excellent operating results, I wouldn’t count the coffee giant out just yet. After all, sales and earnings — as we just saw — continue to grow, and its powerful economic model generates substantial cash flow that it’s increasingly returning to shareholders.

item.title: Hello world!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Welcome to WordPress. This is your first post. Edit or delete it, then start writing!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hi, this is a comment. To get started with moderating, editing, and deleting comments, please visit the Comments screen in the dashboard. Commenter avatars come from Gravatar.

item.title: Stock Recommendations
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This is an example page. It's different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:

Hi there! I'm a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my website. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas. (And gettin' caught in the rain.)

...or something like this:

The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickeys to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.

As a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!

item.title: Privacy Policy
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Who we are

Our website address is: http://motleyfoolinterview.local.

What personal data we collect and why we collect it

Comments

When visitors leave comments on the site we collect the data shown in the comments form, and also the visitor’s IP address and browser user agent string to help spam detection.

An anonymized string created from your email address (also called a hash) may be provided to the Gravatar service to see if you are using it. The Gravatar service privacy policy is available here: https://automattic.com/privacy/. After approval of your comment, your profile picture is visible to the public in the context of your comment.

Media

If you upload images to the website, you should avoid uploading images with embedded location data (EXIF GPS) included. Visitors to the website can download and extract any location data from images on the website.

Contact forms

Cookies

If you leave a comment on our site you may opt-in to saving your name, email address and website in cookies. These are for your convenience so that you do not have to fill in your details again when you leave another comment. These cookies will last for one year.

If you visit our login page, we will set a temporary cookie to determine if your browser accepts cookies. This cookie contains no personal data and is discarded when you close your browser.

When you log in, we will also set up several cookies to save your login information and your screen display choices. Login cookies last for two days, and screen options cookies last for a year. If you select "Remember Me", your login will persist for two weeks. If you log out of your account, the login cookies will be removed.

If you edit or publish an article, an additional cookie will be saved in your browser. This cookie includes no personal data and simply indicates the post ID of the article you just edited. It expires after 1 day.

Embedded content from other websites

Articles on this site may include embedded content (e.g. videos, images, articles, etc.). Embedded content from other websites behaves in the exact same way as if the visitor has visited the other website.

These websites may collect data about you, use cookies, embed additional third-party tracking, and monitor your interaction with that embedded content, including tracking your interaction with the embedded content if you have an account and are logged in to that website.

Analytics

Who we share your data with

If you request a password reset, your IP address will be included in the reset email.

How long we retain your data

If you leave a comment, the comment and its metadata are retained indefinitely. This is so we can recognize and approve any follow-up comments automatically instead of holding them in a moderation queue.

For users that register on our website (if any), we also store the personal information they provide in their user profile. All users can see, edit, or delete their personal information at any time (except they cannot change their username). Website administrators can also see and edit that information.

What rights you have over your data

If you have an account on this site, or have left comments, you can request to receive an exported file of the personal data we hold about you, including any data you have provided to us. You can also request that we erase any personal data we hold about you. This does not include any data we are obliged to keep for administrative, legal, or security purposes.

Where we send your data

Visitor comments may be checked through an automated spam detection service.

Your contact information

Additional information

How we protect your data

What data breach procedures we have in place

What third parties we receive data from

What automated decision making and/or profiling we do with user data

Industry regulatory disclosure requirements

item.title: Buy Starbucks
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The world wants us to believe that investing is hard. Don’t get me wrong, it is. But there are ways to significantly reduce the level of difficulty.

One way to make investing easier is to expand your time horizon. The more decisions you make, the more often you’re going to be wrong. It’s as simple as that. Expanding your time horizon tends to reduce activity and sharpen your focus.

Another way is to buy the world’s greatest companies. Pull up a stock chart for any company that you consider great, and I will almost guarantee that it has an upward sloping trajectory over long periods of time.

These easy-to-implement suggestions do not have to be independent of each other. Indeed, combine the two and you’re on your way to solving what many a pundit wants you to believe is a near impossible endeavour.

This philosophy has underpinned a number of our recommendations thus far, and we’re implementing it again by adding Starbucks (NASDAQ:SBUX) to our collection. A hidden gem this is not, but there’s no doubt it is a gem. Starbucks has generated wonderful long-term returns for its investors, and with multiple growth levers at its disposal, there’s little reason to believe this won’t continue—possibly for decades (yes, decades) to come. While the company’s products help millions get through the day-to-day rigours of life, in our minds, owning this stock will do similar wonders for your portfolio.

The Business

In contrast to many of our recommendations, Starbucks needs little in the way of introduction. There’s a good chance many of you are even customers. After all, this is a company that set out 30 years ago to create the “third place”—an ecosystem outside home and work—by leveraging specialty coffee, seemingly filling a hole in the market left after the television show Cheers (the place where everyone knew your name) went off the air.

But Starbucks has become much more than a place where people flock to get their daily coffee (or five). You might be surprised to learn of the number of brands that have been assembled under the flagship banner over the years. These include Teavana, Tazo, Seattle’s Best Coffee, Evolution Fresh, La Boulange, Ethos, and Frappuccino.

The offerings available within the more than 24,000 stores in the Starbucks chain have also evolved over the years. Frequent visitors know that fresh food and snack offerings have become a significant part of the mix, as well as serve-ware and beverage-making equipment. Starbucks has also leveraged its significant brand by licensing its trademarks through a variety of grocery and food-service accounts.

What started as a single location in 1971 and began to take shape in August 1987, when long-time and current CEO Howard Schultz came on board, has morphed into was is unquestionably the most dominant and disruptive force in the world of coffee.

The Opportunity

When we hear that word disruptive, things like 3D-printing or autonomous automobiles tend to come to mind. Coffee shops generally don’t. However, since Schultz entered the fray, that’s exactly what he’s done to an otherwise staid category. And that’s exactly where Starbucks’s opportunity lies—the continued disruption of the coffee shop industry.

This has been, and continues to be, a multi-pronged attack. Perhaps the most important front is associated with international expansion. It’s no secret that the U.S. (and Canada for that matter) are closer to the point of Starbucks saturation than not. To be clear, there’s still some room for growth within both, but the opportunity has narrowed significantly.

The company long ago recognized this and began allocating significant resources to growth outside its legacy market(s). Growth on the international front has seen the company’s footprint expand across the globe, but the story has really only begun. China, with 2,300 locations spread across 100 cities, is perhaps the best example of the opportunity that continues to exist. To illustrate (and this is purely illustrative), consider that the town in which I reside has a population of 20,000 and one Starbucks location. China has 1.4 billion people. Based on the same ratio, one day there could be 70,000 Starbucks in China alone!

I don’t like the word never, but I think it’s pretty safe to say that this will never happen. I also think it’s safe to say, however, that given the company is confident that it’s made major headway into the whole morning coffee ritual in China (disrupting rituals past), the opportunity goes well beyond the current 2,300 locations.

Beyond international expansion, the other disruptive force that Starbucks brings to the table is its use of technology. This is a company that was very early to adopt mobile pay and, more recently, has introduced an increasingly sophisticated loyalty program. The days of punch card loyalty systems at Fran’s Diner are long gone. And while the number of Starbucks outlets in North America may be approaching the saturation point, thanks to the company’s troves of data, its ability to either extract more from you and me during each visit or entice us to visit more often is gaining strength. This high-tech approach is also being deployed across the globe, helping to build a moat that’s likely to be tough to bridge for any would-be challengers.

Valuation

Great companies don’t always make for great stocks. Typically the reason for this comes down to valuation. Overpay for a great company, and there’s a good chance you’ll regret it. Thanks to a pullback over the past three months or so, Starbucks currently trades at a level that has historically proven to be a fine entry point.

Now, I’m not sure you’ll ever catch me calling a company that trades at 25 times forward earnings “cheap.” However, relative to the rest of the market, that multiple looks pretty darn attractive. Starbucks trades at 142% of the 18 times forward earnings that the S&P 500 currently trades. Relative to the historic relationship between these multiples, this is low. The five-year average premium is 180%, and this metric was as high as 200% in early 2015. All else equal, a return to the average would bump the stock by 26%. At the very least, it’s reasonable to assume a degree of pessimism is built into Starbucks’s stock at current levels.

Risks

I’m hesitant to highlight this given our long-term investment philosophy; however, I think the short-term risks associated with Starbucks are far more significant than the long term. All this means is that when you’re buying the stock, it may prove wise to leave some room to buy more at a later date.

My thinking is based on the market’s relentless focus on Starbucks’s same-store-sales (SSS) growth, especially in the U.S. A print under 5% for the first time in 25 quarters is blamed for the recent stumble by the stock, and, frankly, this could well happen again. After scanning through a few sell-side reports, it’s clear this is all the analysts are focused on. Therefore, a “disappointing” SSS quarterly print in the months ahead could add pressure. It’s important to understand, though, that while this may grab headlines, it’s very unlikely to sway our long-term outlook given the growth levers alluded to earlier—all of which are going to play out over many years.

A more significant risk, in our minds, is the fact that CEO Schultz is 63 and potentially nearing the end of the line. Growing companies require a specific type of leader who is both a visionary and a realist with the ability to make hard decisions in the face of adversity. Schultz has a track record of doing just that (including when he returned to the company in 2008 after stepping down in 2000). Although he is showing no signs of leaving yet, his eventual departure is arguably the largest risk shareholders face.

Foolish Bottom Line

Starbucks offers a fantastic example of how our long-term investment philosophy provides an edge. If we cared a lick about what the SSS print might be in the next quarter, or a year from now even, I’m not sure we’d be recommending this company. But for those willing to ignore the noise and recognize the opportunity that lies in front of the company and the groundwork in place to ensure it comes to fruition, this is a potentially ideal time to begin building a position. While the market is focused on the here and now, we see great things transpiring for both the company and the stock for the next decade and beyond. We’re happy to be ordering up shares and hope that you’ll join us.

item.title: Buy More Starbucks
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Starbucks is a company that really needs no introduction, especially given that this is our second go-around. Allow me though to work in a bit of a golf analogy (as the snow flies outside the window) to outline our thought process that surrounded re-recommending this global behemoth.

For whatever reason, the collection of ideas that surfaced among the team for this month’s U.S. recommendation took the form of a 280-yard par 4 in the mind of yours truly. The golfers out there will know that this kind of approximate yardage generally represents a hole that can be played two ways.

One way is to pull out the driver, swing with all of one’s might, and try to knock it on the green, setting up what’s likely to be a lengthy eagle putt—at best. It’s a “highest risk/highest reward” type scenario. The other way to play is to hit the ball 160 yards or so into the fairway, then play a nice full wedge into the green, ideally setting up a makeable birdie putt—lower risk but still high reward.

You see, it takes all shapes and sizes to build a portfolio. The same goes for the game of golf, where you need to be able to apply any number of shots under all kinds of scenarios. In our opinion though, all portfolios need foundation-like positions from which to build. These generally fit under the “lower risk/high reward” sweet spot—a sweet spot often reserved for the very best companies in the world, of which Starbucks (NASDAQ:SBUX) certainly counts itself.

A few “drive-the-green” ideas were kicked around by the team, but in the end, we’re more than settled with the more conservative, yet potentially very rewarding idea that is Starbucks.

Recap

Our thesis is very much as it was in our first recommendation, but after a quick review, we’re going to drill into what continues to evolve as the big opportunity in front of this company, along with one metric that we think will support this stock very nicely under more adverse market conditions.

Much of our original thesis was centred on the international opportunity in front of Starbucks, and this will be the area that we’re going to dive into in a moment.

First though, I’d like to highlight that what we termed “arguably the largest risk shareholders face” in the original recommendation back in October 2016 has, in some respects, occurred. That risk was the departure of founder, then CEO, and significant shareholder ($2.1 billion worth) Howard Schultz. Now, “departure” probably isn’t the right word, as Schultz remains the executive chairman and has taken the development of higher-end Starbucks shops—Starbucks Reserve Roastery—under his wing. But he is no longer the company’s CEO.

The company’s former COO, Kevin Johnson, has moved into the corner suite, so to speak, and for better or worse, the market more or less gave this development a collective shrug. Perhaps it’d have been a different story if Schultz had left all together, but regardless, we like it when perceived risks don’t turn out as badly as imagined.

The Opportunity

While Schultz has his sleeves rolled up in developing the Roastery angle—an immaterial piece at this stage—the opportunity that we’ll focus on is the one that exists in China.

This is a company that throughout its life has been absolutely tremendous at generating an outsized return on its capital (relative to much of the business world). And that capital cannon, if you will, is currently pointed straight in the direction of China, where it was recently reported that a new Starbucks is opening every 15 hours!

At the end of the last quarter, Starbucks had almost 3,000 stores in China, 550 more than at the beginning of 2017 and well on track to achieve its goal of 5,000 by 2020. The company has spent the better part of two decades crafting the perfect coffeehouse experience in China. These are efforts that are set to pay off in a major way over the next several years. Looking out further, Schultz believes Starbucks’s business in China will eventually exceed the company’s U.S. business, and he is on the record stating, “We are building one of the most respected and iconic brands in the country … I believe China will be as large, or larger, than the U.S. business in the future.”

Should this occur, we believe the current stock price represents a fantastic point of entry.

One Key Metric

Historically, Starbucks has more or less represented the definition of a growth company—with the returns to prove it. And given the China opportunity especially, Starbucks remains firmly in growth mode. However, while the growth engine continues to purr, Starbucks has also become not just a dividend payer, but a dividend grower. And currently, the yield that’s on offer is about as good as it’s ever been at 2.1% or so.

Since instituting a dividend in 2010, Starbucks has increased its annual payouts from $0.18 to the current $1.20 per share. This represents a payout ratio of just 55% of trailing 12-month free cash flow, which indicates that we can expect this dividend growth to continue. Particularly when we consider the company spent about $2 billion repurchasing its stock during the last fiscal year. Recall: these folks know what they’re doing when it comes to capital allocation.

How this serves as potential support for the stock is that based on history, there’s little justification for Starbucks to provide investors with a dividend yield that’s much higher than it currently stands. If the stock sells off for any reason, that yield will move higher, but that, in turn, is likely to attract buyers, keeping the slide in check.

Turning this around, should the stock return to a more mean-like yield of 1.5%, the stock price would have to be $80—40% higher than the current level. And if the dividend payment continues higher—a likely scenario, in our opinion—so too does the potential for capital appreciation based on this metric alone.

Risks and Considerations

Similar risks and considerations remain as they were in our first recommendation. Short term, the market is ever focused on the company’s same-store-sales (SSS) figure, and therefore, quarterly results can cause the stock to get a bit whippy. We pay this no mind.

Bigger picture, rapid growth—regardless of the industry—is a challenge. The execution risk associated with something like coffee versus say, burritos (ahem, Chipotle) is seemingly far less and more focused on marketing/brand awareness, but no doubt, Starbucks could stub a toe, or three, as it pursues this Chinese opportunity. We’ll be mindful of this as we go, but to this point, it’s been a relatively pain-free expansion.

Foolish Bottom Line

Because we’re so aligned with the original recommendation, I’m going to borrow from the close. If we cared a lick about what the SSS print might be in the next quarter or a year from now, I’m not sure we’d be recommending this company. But for those willing to ignore the noise and recognize the opportunity that’s in front of this company, and the ground work in place to ensure it comes to fruition, this is every bit as good a time to begin building a position as it was in October 2016. And similar to the intro note, if you’re moving capital from more speculative positions to begin this build, even better. While the market is focused on the here and now, we see great things transpiring for both the company and the stock for the next decade and beyond. And thus we’re very happy to be ordering up another round of shares. Join us!
